results.title: In song and dance
results.creator_credit: Don Saunders, Lee Robinson, Joy Cavill, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions
results.brief_description: The preparations and some scenes of the 1964 Northern Territory Eisteddfod held at Darwin. Local townspeople are joined by cattlemen and First Nations people from far out stations, and get together to produce an eisteddfod unlike any other - with items of all kinds, from classical ballet to First Nations peoples’ music and dance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Saunders, Lee Robinson, Joy Cavill, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions

results.title: Hunting a kangaroo
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows First nations people out hunting for an important source of food, the kangaroo; using boomerang and woomera which are made especially for the purpose. Introduced by Bill Onus and narrated by John Morgan.

results.title: Game Masters: Yuji Naka interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yuji Naka is a videogame designer and programmer, best known as the former head of Sonic Team, where he was the lead programmer of the original ‘Sonic the Hedgehog’. Naka reveals his initial desire to make arcade games and the influence that Yu Suzuki has had on his career as a programmer. Since 2006 he has been the head of Prope, an independent game company he founded after leaving SEGA.
Yuji gives great insights into the development and creation of ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 1 and 2’, ‘Nights into Dreams’ and ‘Chu Chu Rocket’.
NB: This interview was conducted in Yuji Naka’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This film opens with shots of snow-capped mountains, Mt Spion Kopje and Mt Bogong, as a backdrop to the surrounding green bushland. Cutting a swathe through the bush is a dirt track lined with electricity transmission towers.

On the mountain, we see children and adults learning to use their skis. There are lots of falls and numerous attempts to stand up again. There is some sled action on a type of sled typical to the era, and a big home-made metal sled with steering. Everyone herringbones back up the slope. Using the rope tow and ducking under the return rope .

We see skiers ski in front of a building with the signage “Ski School”.

There are lovely individual scenes of a man and a woman skiing past the camera dressed in the ski fashion of the day. A group of people practise their ski moves in front of the “Falls Creek Comfort Station”.

Colourfully dressed children navigate the ski slopes, and an elderly man dressed in a coat and feathered trilby-style hat tries his hand at skiing.

We see a lovely scene of the family as they take a break from skiing to have a picnic sitting in the snow. They have their thermos flask, sandwiches, and cordial.

The film shows people being towed uphill and past a building with “ski lodge” signage.

There are various scenes of skiers congregating together on the slopes and wide shots of them skiing in across and down the slopes.

The final part of the film shows what could be accommodation Bogong Village. The village was originally constructed by the Victorian State Electricity Utility Commissions (SEC) from the 1930s and 1950s to house workers on the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme.

We see historic vehicles c1950/ 1960 with Victorian registration plates beginning with HEW: 4, parked in the street at the front of the houses. There are images of people as they walk down the street with the mountains in the background.

This film shows good examples of fashion, ski wear, and ski techniques in the 60s. Ski Lodge architecture, Bogong Village architecture, vehicles and Falls Creek and Bogong Village landscapes are also a great historic reflection of the era.

Originally made using 16mm film

Selected highlights list:

00:05:23:00 Close up of above

results.title: Tour of Tasmania, February 1950
results.brief_description: Home movie travelogue of Tasmania shot in February 1950. Includes scenes of several historic buildings and sites, and of Swansea, Port Arthur, Hobart and Cataract Gorge. No credits available.

results.title: Circling the globe in comfort
results.creator_credit: Jaaf Nieuwenhuis and Royal Rotterdam Lloyd
results.brief_description: Historical documentary of a round-the-world trip by the 23,000 ton Dutch liner, the “Willem Ruys”, beginning from Sydney and calling into Wellington (NZ), Lima (Peru), Balboa (Panama City), Miami, Bermuda, Southampton, Rotterdam, passing Portugal, Gibraltar and Malta to Port Said and into the Suez Canal. From the Suez Canal the voyage then continues on through the Red Sea to aden, into the Indian Ocean to Colombo, then Singapore, across the Equator past Java and Christmas Island to Cape Leeuwin and finally arriving in Melbourne.

results.title: What if Succession was a romantic comedy?
results.material_description: digital screen recording of Limimalist's YouTube post
results.brief_description: HBO’s Succession is a brilliant tragicomedy about how the combination of capital and intergenerational trauma corrupts absolutely – but you wouldn’t know that from the online fanbase. In this video, Liminalist recuts series footage to create a romantic comedy-style trailer about Tom Wambsgans and Greg Hirsch. Through deft editing and a boppy soundtrack, the trailer reframes their jibes and banter as a blossoming romance. Following the series finale, the video went viral thanks to ‘TomGreg shippers’, a subgroup of fans who make content about their loving but sadistic friendship – or theorise that it might be something more.

results.title: Heart disease
results.brief_description: Neil created this story as a document of how surviving a heart attack completely changed his life. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story / Telling Stories, Building Communities’ Digital Storytelling Project ACMI in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) and supported by Vic Health.

results.title: From Graz to Glenroy
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Elfrieda Senycia and Viv Mehes
results.brief_description: This story explores the journey of migration from Austria to Australia for Elfrida and her husband. As they rebuild life in a new country they deal with triumps and disappointments including the humiliation of never having their qualifications recognised in Australia.
